newsitem.title: USA: IMC, Freeport sees more DAP sales.
newsitem.headline: IMC, Freeport sees more DAP sales.

text.p: Freeport-McMoRan Resource Partners LP and IMC Global said their IMC-Agrico Co fertilizer joint venture has resulted in 300,000 tonnes of additional exports of phosphate fertilizers in the second quarter.
"A lull in international demand appears to have ended," said Thomas C. Pasztor, spokesman for IMC-Agrico. "We ship monthly to China, so this is in addition to contract business that is ongoing."
The private sales were completed in late March by the Phosphate Chemical Export Association, which is a partnership between IMC-Agrico and Potash Corp. of Saskatchewan.
Approximately half of the sales will go to China, Pasztor said. Other destinations include India, Brazil, Chile and Mexico.
The additional fertilizer was sold for shipment during April, May and June for the market price at the time of loading, IMC said.
The amount of the additional export business is not seen as noteworthy for U.S. markets, but the extra sales will support current prices, industry sources said.
"The reason it is significant is because it lends stability to the market price," a dealer said. "If there is sufficient stability, it allows them to increase production and maintain prices."
China imports about 4.5 to 6.0 million tonnes of diammonium phosphate (DAP) each year, absorbing approximately one-third of the world's available supply for export, cash sources said.
U.S. fertilizer manufacturers produce approximately 1.2 to 1.4 million tonnes each month, cash market sources said.
"So when you hear that China takes another 150,000 (tonnes) a quarter, it sounds like a lot, but it really isn't when you consider the big picture," one source said.
Under its current two-year contract agreement with China, PCEA ships approximately four Panamax cargos (200,000 tonnes) to China each month, industry sources said.
